bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Sylvanus Griswold Morley, December 12, 1928

div1.p: Carter thanks Morley for meeting with her in Washington to provide assistance with Mayan references for the History of Yellow Fever and asks him to send her more information when he gets to Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Sylvanus Griswold Morley, December 12, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Bibliography
Morley
DIVISION
//////
----------------------------------
Address:
Miss Laura A. Carter,
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., H. W.
Washington, D. C. U. S. A.
December 12, 1928.
Dr. Sylvanus Griswold Morley,
Carnegie Institution of Washington,
Sixteenth and P Streets, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sylvanus:
div1.p:
As per our conversation of to-day I am enclosing the Spanish
text of the three new entries from the book of Chilan Balam of
Tizimin, which you sent me September 17, 1926. This, in order
that, as soon as you return to Mexico, you get and send me the Mayan
text of the aforesaid entries and also send me the English trans-
lation. I hope, with you, that this material may reach me in time
to be incorporated in Father's book, for I know how pleased he
would have been at this addition data you have obtained re “ vómi-
tos de sangre,” having apparently arrived with the Spaniards.
Your findings (in these new entries) will add to the value of the
book, but unless they should arrive as promptly as possible, since it will be impossible to
hold up the book for them. The book is needed as “ammunition” in
the yellow fever campaign, and, when it once gets to the publisher, it
will, I am sure, be pushed through at record speed. However, I
hope and believe there is yet time to incorporate these entries
in the MS. Ojalá!

In returning this material lc Pplease give me all possible data as to imprint, pagination
etc. etc. especially if the Mayan MS has been published.

Thank you for a very illuminating day: You helped me a
great deal yourself and gave me data wherewith I can help myself
still more.

With recuerdos carinosos to yourself and Frances, and tell
her to keep on being your Conscience until I get this Tizimin matter
settled!
div1.closer:
Como siempre, Laura Hope I'll see you both before you leave. I know you're
“working your head off:” so am I, but I should be delighted to have
you and Frances to anything from breakfast to dinner, or even to see you
off at Union Station, if I “can no more!”
Enclosure.
Mem.
As I have also stated at the heading of the enclosed Spanish
text, there is still lacking to complete this material for publica-
tion: andof which please (a') Give imprint and pagination if published
(a) Mayan text, of which you sent Spanish translation./
(b) English translation of Mayan text and Spanish (if they differ)
(c) Check enclosed Spanish text with original and (c') give im-
print and pagination if it has been published.
(d) Christian chronology for these entries for Katun 4 Ahau--and
please, for my sake! make 'em “fool proof.” I inherit neither Father's
fondness nor facility for “figgering out” the exact date at which
things occurred in the Mayan records. Indeed my idea of --purgatory
would be to be a time-keeper for a Mayan gang working on the Temple
of the Warriors!

M. S. de Tizimin - fol. 17 V.

“En este Ahau-Katún (4 Ahau Katun) hubo una epidémia de Vómitos
de sangre, y fué la época en que anduvieron con los calzones rotos
y con las ropas despedazadas. El pan escasoaba muvho. Nos llegan
retonos y nosllega el carnero que bala, y nos llega tambien el caballo.
Se recoge el tributo en Chicheen.”
M. S. de Tizimin - fol. 20 v.
“4 Ahau 11° de la rserie. Se erige Katún en Chicheen-itzá.
Nos llega el fuego, nos llega la promavera, nos llega Ah-Kantenal, nos
llega el Vómito de sangre. Por cuarta vez nos llega la palabra de
Kukulean, dieiéndole el porvenir a los Itzaes.”
M. S. de Tizimin - fol. 142 v.

“En Ucí es en donde se erige el monumento del Katún en el
4 Ahau. En tiempo venidero se erigirá en Chicheen, al Sur. Los que
cultivan las milpas están con la cara tapada y con los ojos mortecinos,
llorando sus mazorcas, llorando su pan. Ensangrentamos mucho su estera
y su locho. Hubo epidemia de Vómitos de sangre. Durante el dia, con
la ropa blanoa, tiene en las manos el pan que pide. Nos llegan retoños,
nos llega el pave real, nos llegan las teas, nos llega el español, nos
llega la alforja para ella grupa del caballo y nos llega el caballo. Se
recoge el tributo en Chicheen.”
